awd_titl_txt: SI2-SSE: Highly Efficient and Scalable Software for Coarse-Grained Molecular Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Molecular simulation provides a powerful complement to conventional experimental techniques, offering both high-resolution information and unusual levels of control over the experimental conditions. While atomic-resolution molecular simulations are well established and widely used, it is also possible to remove extraneous detail from molecular representations to create highly efficient "coarse-grained" (CG) models. CG approaches can expand the potential applications of molecular simulations far beyond atomic-resolution models: the computational efficiency of CG models allows the scientist to investigate not only significantly larger systems, but also phenomena that require significantly longer time scales. These CG approaches are of particular interest in the study of systems where key aspects of various processes emerge from interactions between large numbers of molecules over relatively long distances. CG models can therefore provide crucial insight into the molecular basis of such systems, e.g., new materials. However, CG models can require significant scientific understanding to create and use effectively. To bring cutting-edge CG methodologies into a wider degree of use, this project will implement key algorithmic advances and associated CG functionalities into the widely-used LAMMPS molecular dynamics simulation code. Furthermore, the project will implement a publically-accessible repository for CG model parameters and input files to accelerate the dissemination of exemplar CG models throughout the scientific community.


The project will integrate key functionalities for very large-scale and dynamic CG models into the LAMMPS molecular dynamics package. These functionalities include not only sparse memory optimizations (e.g., template molecular topology descriptions and spatial data structures for link cell algorithms) but also user-defined transition information for the propagation of "ultra-coarse-grained" (UCG) models; parameterization of the latter can be achieved by using the integrated multi-scale coarse-grained force matching code (MSCGFM). Furthermore, direct incorporation of experimental data into CG models will be assisted by implementations of the "experiment directed metadynamics" (EDM) and "experiment directed simulation" (EDS) algorithms. Taken together, these enhancements will provide cutting-edge CG model generation and simulation techniques to a wide user community. To complement the extended functionality of the LAMMPS code, a user-driven data and metadata repository for CG models will be provided to assist with efficient dissemination of model parameters and simulation/validation data to the scientific community.

por.por_cntn:
Scientists today are capable of studying processes at the subcellular level, but the methods used have significant drawbacks. There is currently no way to directly observe the movement and behavior of entire biological systems at the atomic scale. To overcome this, computational techniques such as molecular dynamics are available. Molecular dynamics simulates a system of interest atom by atom, with the attractive and repulsive interactions between each atom evolving the system over time through a series of discrete steps.

Molecular dynamics is a powerful tool to study systems beyond the reach of experimental techniques, but it is limited by the computational power required to simulate larger systems for longer periods of time. Often, the systems being studied are far larger than current computers can handle. In these cases, one possible solution is coarse-graining (or CG), in which the atomic scale system is replaced by a lower resolution one, in which individual coarse-grained sites stand in for entire groups of atoms.  This allows for the simulation of larger systems because of the reduction in the number of particles and by allowing each time step in the simulation to cover more time. These CG models can be developed in one of two ways. First, models can be created by hand, where interactions between sites are selected in order to match certain physical properties about the system being coarse-grained. This is known as top down CG. The second option, or bottom up CG, is done by using algorithms to define the interactions between particles using smaller all-atom molecular dynamics as inputs. Bottom up CG models have the advantage of being systematic and simple to produce because of that, and are thus attractive prospects for researchers who wish to make a coarse-grained model of a new system.

Using the funds provided by the NSF, we have created a powerful and easy to use toolbox to generate bottom up CG from all-atom simulation data called OpenMSCG. This software enables users to convert atomistic data onto arbitrary CG mappings, perform a variety of bottom up CG algorithms, and convert that output into ready-to-use inputs for further CG simulation. Currently, the code supports Multiscale Coarse-Graining (MSCG), Relative Entropy Minimization (REM), heterogeneous elastic Network Models (hENM), Essential Dynamics Coarse-Graining (CGED), and Ultra-Coarse-Graining (UCG).  Our web portal, located at https://software.rcc.uchicago.edu/mscg/, contains not only the code which can be downloaded and used for free by anyone, but also detailed documentation, a series of tutorials to teach users how to use the code, and a repository for CG models built with the software, which will be grown as users submit their models for others to utilize. The code is written under the GNU General Public License and thus anyone is free to modify the code to suit their own needs.

The software that has come from this grant allows for CG models to be developed by practically anyone. This greatly increases the scale of simulations available to researchers all over the world, especially those who do not have access to high performance supercomputing resources. Many systems that are made accessible through coarse-graining are relevant to the study and treatment of a variety of diseases. For example, understanding viral assembly is critical to hampering their infectivity, but those processes involve many millions of atoms over periods as long as hours, far outside the current scope of all-atom simulation, and yet too difficult to resolve via experiment. Currently CG models are currently being developed for viruses such as HIV, and the coronavirus responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic.

Modified by: Gregory A Voth
